text:
Dear NMFS,

As an angler, I am opposed to plans to revitalize the U.S. Atlantic pelagic longline fishery. This goal comes at the expense of bluefin tuna, marlin, and the recreational fishing industry, which generates hundreds of thousands of jobs and contributes billions to the economy. Many of the options put forth in the Scoping Document do not further fish conservation or stock recovery.

I ask the National Marine Fisheries Service to, instead of bolstering the fishery responsible for closures and gear restrictions, take action to bolster bluefin tuna and marlin fish stocks. At a minimum, the "no action" option should be taken to maintain current closures and restricted areas. Please consider management options that achieve greater conservation benefits for Atlantic bluefin tuna and marlin.

Thank you,

Name Dale A Miles
label: neg
docAbstract: NMFS announces its intent to prepare a draft EIS to assess the potential effects of alternative measures under the 2006 Consolidated Atlantic Highly Migratory Species Fishery Management Plan (2006 Consolidated HMS FMP) for management of the pelagic longline fishery.  This notice announces a public process for determining the scope of issues to be addressed and for identifying the significant issues relating to the management of Atlantic HMS, with a focus on area-based management measures and weak hook management measures that were implemented to reduce dead discards of bluefin tuna in the pelagic longline fishery.  NMFS would use the scoping process and the draft EIS to develop a regulatory amendment applicable to the pelagic longline fishery.  The scoping process and draft EIS are intended to determine if the suite of existing measures are the best means of achieving the current management objectives and providing flexibility to adapt to fishing variability in the future, consistent with the 2006 Consolidated HMS FMP, the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (Magnuson-Stevens Act), the Atlantic Tunas Convention Act (ATCA), and other relevant Federal laws.  NMFS is also announcing the availability of a scoping document describing potential measures for inclusion in a future regulatory amendment.  NMFS will hold scoping meetings to gather public comment on potential management options for area based and weak hook requirements.  The time and location details of the scoping meetings are available in the SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION section of this notice.  NMFS is requesting comments on this NOI and the management of Atlantic bluefin tuna, which includes management options that are described in the scoping document, and relevant options that would meet the purpose and need for this action.

text:
The stated mission of the EPA is to PROTECT Americans from harmful contaminants in the environment (i.e. contamination in the air we breath and the water we drink). The coal ash produced by electric utilities that burn coal contains such high levels of contaminants that regulations to manage (reduce) exposure to air and water are ESSENTIAL. DO NOT make the proposed changes would diminish the current regulations for Management of Coal Ash Disposal and leave the environment at risk. The EPA would be guilty of putting the Fox in charge of the Hen House!!

Gerry Friedman
Labadie, Missouri
label: neg
docAbstract: The EPA is publishing a proposed rule addressing specific technical issues on which the Agency agreed to a remand as a result of litigation of the final Coal Combustion Residuals (CCR) Disposal Rule, published April 17, 2015. Issues covered by this proposal will include, but are not limited to, the height limitation of the vegetative slopes of dikes; the type and magnitude of non-groundwater releases that would require a facility to comply with some or all of the corrective action procedures set forth in the final CCR rule; and adding boron to the list of contaminants in Appendix IV of the final CCR rule that trigger the corrective action requirements under the final rule.

text:
Dear Secretary Zinke and the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management,

I stand in opposition to the proposed 2019 offshore oil and gas lease sales in the U.S. Arctic?s Beaufort Sea. Under the current 2017-2022 OCS Oil and Gas Leasing Program, lease sales in the Beaufort Sea are prohibited. Initiating the leasing process prior to the finalization and approval of a new 5-year program is reckless and premature. BOEM?s action to solicit industry nominations for new lease areas indicates that a decision to offer leases in the Beaufort Sea has already been made, rendering the public process that allows for stakeholder input meaningless.

The Arctic is one of the most diverse and environmentally significant regions on the planet. The region is home to many important marine animals, including beluga whales, polar bears, seals, walrus, migratory birds, and fish. Offshore drilling in this pristine environment would not only jeopardize sensitive marine ecosystems, but also the communities and species that rely on its continued abundance. There is no proven way to clean up oil spilled in sea ice. Unless and until we can prove that drilling in the Arctic Ocean can be done safely, it is a risk we simply cannot afford to take.

We urge the immediate reconsideration of the irresponsible 2019 Beaufort Sea Lease Sale.

Sincerely,
Michael Mecham
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The purpose of the Call for Information and Nominations is to solicit industry nominations and gather information on the area from all interested parties for consideration in planning future OCS oil and gas lease sales.

This way, it would be easier for both the Consulate and the person applying for the visa at the time of the interview. This would allow the all the security checks to be processed and cleared before the interview, so the officer at the consulate could determine a final decision during the interview and not having the applicant to wait for a long time. The process of being waiting for an unframed time now is very frustrating. Families are being separated and children are really facing a hard time dealing with the separation. I am a wife whose husband is in Mexico waiting for a response. I am here with my two children and we just don't know how much longer we are going to be waiting for a response. It really hurts!
If the process can be a part of the DS 260 application it would really help a lot.

Thank you so much!!

text:
As a recreational angler and conservationist, I support Amendment 43 to the Fishery Management Plan for the Snapper-Grouper Fishery of the South Atlantic Region that would allow a limited opening of the red snapper fishery in South Atlantic federal waters.

I support opening a South Atlantic red snapper season in 2018, through Amendment 43, that balances season length with sustainability. The South Atlantic red snapper stock has increased in abundance over the last several years at an even faster rate than predicted by the rebuilding plan. Abundance surveys and angler reports point to a quickly rebuilding fishery. Opening a conservative season as proposed will not only provide access and opportunity for anglers, but will also provide much needed data for a more accurate assessment of the red snapper stock.

In conclusion, I support Snapper Grouper Amendment 43 and urge swift final approval by the Secretary of Commerce.

Thank you for your consideration.
label: pos
docAbstract: NMFS proposes regulations to implement Amendment 43.  In November 2017, NMFS implemented an emergency rule that set the 2017 commercial and recreational annual catch limit (ACL) for red snapper in the South Atlantic at 42,510 fish.  Prior to the recent emergency action, the ACL was zero and harvest was not allowed since 2014.  The actions in Amendment 43 will remove the process and equation used to determine the red snapper ACL as specified in Amendment 28 to the Snapper-Grouper FMP.  In addition, this action will specify a total ACL equal to 42,510 fish, a commercial ACL equal to 124,815 pounds (whole weight), and a recreational ACL equal to 29,656 fish to allow harvest of red snapper beginning in 2018.   The action is expected  to reduce, to the extent practicable, existing adverse socio-economic impacts to fishermen and fishing communities that utilize the red snapper portion of the snapper-grouper fishery, without overfishing, and while continuing to rebuild the stock as per the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act.

text:
I am opposed to any regulation on bump stocks.

These proposed regulations would declare a bump stock to be a machinegun because it allows the gun to fire more than one shot by a single PULL of the trigger -- that is, by a single volitional function of the finger.

But federal law, at 26 U.S.C. 5845(b), defines a part as a machinegun ONLY if it is designed solely and exclusively to allow the gun to fire more than one shot ... by a single FUNCTION of the trigger.

To state the obvious, a finger is not the same thing as a trigger. And, while a bump stock is in operation, the trigger functions separately every time a round is discharged.

So these regulations are proposing a radical change -- as they effectively define a gun as a machinegun even if the trigger resets for every round that is fired, so long as the finger only pulls the trigger once.

While bump stock devices will now be treated as machineguns under these regulations, they also raise serious questions in regard to AR-15s and other semi-automatic rifles -- as they are now on the brink of being designated as machineguns by the next anti-gun administration.

In the past, one had to fundamentally change the firing mechanism of a semi-automatic firearm to convert it into a fully automatic firearm.

But now according to these regulations, a bump stock is a machinegun -- and it can "readily restore" a semi-auto into a machinegun, simply because the gun owner can effectively fire the weapon continuously with a single pull of the trigger. This would invoke the statutory definition for a rifle, which is classified as a machinegun (26 USC 5845(b)).

It wont matter that a gun which is being bump fired has not been fundamentally altered. AR-15s will be on the brink of extinction once these regulations go into force.

These regulations dismiss Second Amendment protections, by appealing to the Heller court decision. But the Constitution trumps the Supreme Court -- so when the Second Amendment says that the right to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed, any limitation of the right for law-abiding citizens should be treated as unconstitutional.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The Department of Justice anticipates issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that would interpret the statutory definition of “machinegun” in the National Firearms Act of 1934 and Gun Control Act of 1968 to clarify whether certain devices, commonly known as “bump fire” stocks, fall within that definition. Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

In November 2017, NMFS implemented an emergency rule that set the 2017 commercial and recreational annual catch limit (ACL) for red snapper in the South Atlantic at 42,510 fish.  Prior to the recent emergency action, the ACL was zero and harvest was not allowed since 2014.  The actions in Amendment 43 will remove the process and equation used to determine the red snapper ACL as specified in Amendment 28 to the Snapper-Grouper FMP.  In addition, this action will specify a total ACL equal to 42,510 fish, a commercial ACL equal to 124,815 pounds (whole weight), and a recreational ACL equal to 29,656 fish to allow harvest of red snapper beginning in 2018.   The action is expected  to reduce, to the extent practicable, existing adverse socio-economic impacts to fishermen and fishing communities that utilize the red snapper portion of the snapper-grouper fishery, without overfishing, and while continuing to rebuild the stock as per the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act.

text:
As a recreational angler and conservationist, I support Amendment 43 to the Fishery Management Plan for the Snapper-Grouper Fishery of the South Atlantic Region that would allow a limited opening of the red snapper fishery in South Atlantic federal waters.

I support opening a South Atlantic red snapper season in 2018, through Amendment 43, that balances season length with sustainability. The South Atlantic red snapper stock has increased in abundance over the last several years at an even faster rate than predicted by the rebuilding plan. Abundance surveys and angler reports point to a quickly rebuilding fishery. Opening a conservative season as proposed will not only provide access and opportunity for anglers, but will also provide much needed data for a more accurate assessment of the red snapper stock.

In conclusion, I support Snapper Grouper Amendment 43 and urge swift final approval by the Secretary of Commerce.

Thank you for your consideration.

text:
Dear Secretary Zinke and the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management,

I stand in opposition to the proposed 2019 offshore oil and gas lease sales in the U.S. Arctic?s Beaufort Sea. Under the current 2017-2022 OCS Oil and Gas Leasing Program, lease sales in the Beaufort Sea are prohibited. Initiating the leasing process prior to the finalization and approval of a new 5-year program is reckless and premature. BOEM?s action to solicit industry nominations for new lease areas indicates that a decision to offer leases in the Beaufort Sea has already been made, rendering the public process that allows for stakeholder input meaningless.

The Arctic is one of the most diverse and environmentally significant regions on the planet. The region is home to many important marine animals, including beluga whales, polar bears, seals, walrus, migratory birds, and fish. Offshore drilling in this pristine environment would not only jeopardize sensitive marine ecosystems, but also the communities and species that rely on its continued abundance. There is no proven way to clean up oil spilled in sea ice. Unless and until we can prove that drilling in the Arctic Ocean can be done safely, it is a risk we simply cannot afford to take.

We urge the immediate reconsideration of the irresponsible 2019 Beaufort Sea Lease Sale.

Sincerely,
Amy Graf
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The purpose of the Call for Information and Nominations is to solicit industry nominations and gather information on the area from all interested parties for consideration in planning future OCS oil and gas lease sales.

label: verypos
docAbstract: The Department of Justice anticipates issuing a Notice of Proposed Rulemaking (NPRM) that would interpret the statutory definition of “machinegun” in the National Firearms Act of 1934 and Gun Control Act of 1968 to clarify whether certain devices, commonly known as “bump fire” stocks, fall within that definition. Before doing so, the Department and ATF need to gather information and comments from the public and industry regarding the nature and scope of the market for these devices.

text:
Without my dad knowing, he came home from WWII with tuberculosis and transmitted this disease to me. Although rare, my diagnosis is a fused hip secondary to tuberculosis. At age 2, my right hip socket was removed and my hip was fused with a bone taken from my left leg. Walking, sitting, and standing have always been challenging, tiring, and painful. Now that I am 70, my life is greatly limited due to physical pain and exhaustion from living in a handicapped body for 68 years.

I can't wrap my head around why our government of "We The People" are treating chronic pain patients and their families to more suffering! Pain medications help us to live our lives with some relief from our day in day out physical pain and struggles. These medications are Needed because of diseases and injuries that we didn't want nor did we ask for them. A shortage in pain medication will only hurt those who are already hurting. Chronic Pain Patients, the Forgotten! Thank you.

text: Clearly some reform is needed to stem the rise of addiction, but limiting production without a concomitant assurance that pain medications will still be available in adequate supply to those persons, patients with chronic pain, who actually need these medications is not a solution. In fact, it will only increase suffering (albeit of a different kind) for chronic pain sufferers and their families. Pursuing a sensible, fair, solution that serves the needs of these patients whilst reducing unnecessary prescribing is what is needed.

Please take note that maple syrup is just that: syrup from maple trees. The collected tree sap somewhat thickens as it boils down into a wonderful syrup like no other. There is nothing added to it. It is PURE, all natural, a gift from Mother Nature! It has been in the trees for centuries, all the while with no added sugar... imagine that! There is a MAJOR difference between what is pure and what has added sugar. Pure: nothing added. Added sugar: scoop sugar and add to the original product. This DOES NOT happen with maple syrup nor with honey and I dearly take offence even to the suggestion of it! Any such label is an out right lie!

Anyone that thinks for the slightest second that there is added sugar in pure maple syrup (or pure honey) has obviously been putting the wrong stuff on their pancakes, waffles, ice cream, ham, sausages, into their desserts, sauces, etc!
I believe you'll not find one Vermonter that will stand by such nonsense! We take great pride in these natural products which have developed naturally and through laborious time honored traditions.

text:
As a recreational angler and conservationist, I support Amendment 43 to the Fishery Management Plan for the Snapper-Grouper Fishery of the South Atlantic Region that would allow a limited opening of the red snapper fishery in South Atlantic federal waters.

I support opening a South Atlantic red snapper season in 2018, through Amendment 43, that balances season length with sustainability. The South Atlantic red snapper stock has increased in abundance over the last several years at an even faster rate than predicted by the rebuilding plan. Abundance surveys and angler reports point to a quickly rebuilding fishery. Opening a conservative season as proposed will not only provide access and opportunity for anglers, but will also provide much needed data for a more accurate assessment of the red snapper stock.

In conclusion, I support Snapper Grouper Amendment 43 and urge swift final approval by the Secretary of Commerce.

Thank you for your consideration.
label: pos
docAbstract: NMFS proposes regulations to implement Amendment 43.  In November 2017, NMFS implemented an emergency rule that set the 2017 commercial and recreational annual catch limit (ACL) for red snapper in the South Atlantic at 42,510 fish.  Prior to the recent emergency action, the ACL was zero and harvest was not allowed since 2014.  The actions in Amendment 43 will remove the process and equation used to determine the red snapper ACL as specified in Amendment 28 to the Snapper-Grouper FMP.  In addition, this action will specify a total ACL equal to 42,510 fish, a commercial ACL equal to 124,815 pounds (whole weight), and a recreational ACL equal to 29,656 fish to allow harvest of red snapper beginning in 2018.   The action is expected  to reduce, to the extent practicable, existing adverse socio-economic impacts to fishermen and fishing communities that utilize the red snapper portion of the snapper-grouper fishery, without overfishing, and while continuing to rebuild the stock as per the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act.

I am opposed to any attempt to repeal or weaken clean water protections around toxic coal ash.

Clean water is the lifeblood of our communities, but too many of us have to worry about pollution leaking from coal ash ponds, threatening our drinking water and the health of our families.

We cannot rely on the utilities and coal ash pond operators to set their own standards or decide if they want to clean up their pollution, as your current proposal allows. These and a host of other provisions in the proposal, like eliminating requirements for leaking ponds to install liners, seem to prioritize industry profits over our public health, and should be abandoned.

text:
I write to express my opposition to your March 15, 2018, proposal to weaken the critical protections provided by the 2015 coal ash rule. Below I outline how your proposal will leave communities and our environment vulnerable to toxic coal ash contamination and catastrophic spills.

GUTTING OF GROUNDWATER PROTECTION STANDARDS: I oppose your proposal to weaken the groundwater protection standards. Thousands of massive, aging coal ash pits are leaking heavy metals and toxic pollutants into groundwater. Coal ash dumping has led to water contamination and disastrous coal ash spills. Your proposal to allow states and polluters to use "alternative" groundwater protection standards for determining when cleanup is required will only enable states and polluters to hide the truth about contamination.

GUTTING OF GROUNDWATER MONITORING REQUIREMENTS: The public deserves to know if coal ash dumps in their communities are contaminating groundwater. The groundwater monitoring requirements are vitally important to the more than 15 million households in the U.S. that rely on private wells for drinking water. It's unconscionable to allow polluters to decide when groundwater monitoring should stop.

GUTTING OF CLEANUP REQUIREMENTS: Empowering polluters to avoid cleanup will result in ongoing water contamination. Allowing states or the owners of leaking dumps to determine whether cleanup or closure is necessary is dangerous. Coal ash is toxic, and weakening current standards to match those of town dumps endangers all communities that are near coal ash ponds and landfills. And just because a coal ash dump is no longer receiving waste doesn't mean that it no longer poses a threat to health and the environment. I oppose your proposal to treat coal ash like household garbage and to reduce the 30-year post-closure monitoring period for dumps that are no longer receiving waste.

GUTTING OF LOCATION RESTRICTIONS: Prohibitions on dumping coal ash in groundwater, wetlands, floodplains, fault zones, seismic zones and unstable areas are commonsense requirements that prevent water contamination. I oppose your proposal to give states and polluters the discretion to ignore crucial and life-saving location prohibitions (and to do so without public notification or oversight), and reject any extension of the October 2018 deadline to comply with these requirements.

GUTTING CLOSURE REQUIREMENTS FOR LEAKING UNLINED DUMPS: I strongly oppose your proposal to give states and polluters the discretion not to close or retrofit dangerous leaking unlined pits. If these leaking dumps are allowed to operate, they will keep polluting our drinking water and waterways and continue to threaten catastrophic spills.

THE EPAS CURRENT RULEMAKING PROCESS IS FLAWED AND LIMITS PUBLIC INPUT: The EPA has failed to consider widespread evidence of overwhelming groundwater contamination before proposing to weaken the coal ash rule. Industry data shows arsenic in groundwater near ash dumps exceeds federal drinking water standards at most plants. Dangerous levels of lead, thallium, selenium or radium are also very common. Moreover, 45 days is far too short a time for the public to provide meaningful comment. By failing to hold any field hearings in impacted communities, the EPA is silencing the voices of those directly harmed.

I urge you to protect us from coal ash and preserve all of the minimum protections provided by the 2015 coal ash rule.

Regards,
Julie Alley

text:
I am writing in opposition to weakening of the Coal Combustion Residuals Rule (CCR Rule). I live very near the coal ash pit on the Cumberland River in Tennessee and also near Gallatin, TN. Tennessee waterways have been negatively affected by coal ash spills. The new proposal by the EPA will weaken protections for our waterways that currently protect them from coal ash spills. This has potential very expensive impacts on human health and quality of life. In addition, the EPA proposes to let the coal companies themselves set the standards for protection of our land and waterways. The EPAs proposed weakening of this national coal ash rule will almost certainly lead to delays in cleanup of spills, less effective cleanup, or no cleanup at all, even when politically-powerful utilities such as the Tennessee Valley Authority illegally pollute our groundwater and drinking water supplies.

We need clear, strong, well-enforced federal regulation of coal ash disposal to protect the citizens of coal-producing states. Please protect the public and not well-financed utilities.

Please maintain strong federal oversight of coal ash desposal; protect our waterways. Thank you for your attention to this matter.

Mary Moore
Clarksville, TN

text:
I am writing to urge you to reconsider repealing the Clean Power Plan. In my opinion this would be a huge mistake that would have numerous health and economic impacts.
Scientific evidence has shown that greenhouse gases are pollutants that endanger public health. The Clean Power Plan was created to limit greenhouse gases. The vast majority of climate scientists agree that climate change is real and is happening at an even faster pace than originally predicted. Climate Change is one of the biggest issues we all are going to have to deal with. It is going to be a huge challenge that we need to work on together regardless of partisan politics.
Greenhouse gases created in power production are the largest industrial source of these pollutants. These pollutants cause many health issues such as asthma. There are many economic impacts including lost time in school and work due to health issues. The EPA has previously reported that the C.P. P. would prevent 90,000 asthma attacks, 300,000 missed work and school days and 3,600 premature deaths by 2030. Other economic impacts could be more heating and cooling costs due to extreme weather conditions. Also flooding damage and foundation repairs due to droughts and flooding. There are also economic impacts to the tourism industry.
The U.S. constitution reads "We the People". It was created to protect the people. Not Corporations! The EPA was also created to protect the people of America. In the EPA mission statement it states the mission is to protect the people.
The EPA did not follow procedural rules that govern rule making in making the new rule to repeal the C.P.P.
Please reconsider and do the right thing and keep the clean power plan in place to protect the people now and for future generations.
label: veryneg
docAbstract: The EPA is taking action to repeal the Carbon Pollution Emission Guidelines for Existing Stationary Sources: Electric Utility Generating Units (EGUs), commonly referred to as the Clean Power Plan, as promulgated October 23, 2015. The EPA is also proposing the Affordable Clean Energy rule which would establish emission guidelines for states to develop plans to address greenhouse gas emissions from existing coal-fired power plants. The ACE rule would replace the 2015 Clean Power Plan, which EPA has proposed to repeal because it exceeded EPA's authority.

text:
I am writing today in regard to the EPA's proposed repeal of the Clean Power Plan, as the proposed regulatory change of the CPP is grounded in shaky legal ground and a loose interpretation of facts.

The proposed change stems from Executive Order 13783, which mandates a review of all federal regulations that "potentially burden the development or use of domestically produced energy resources and appropriately suspend... those that unduly burden the development of domestic energy resources beyond the degree necessary to protect the public interest or otherwise comply with the law".

First, the proposed rule is ignoring the importance of the CPP to the public interest. Climate change is a real and ongoing phenomenon that is caused by human-induced emissions into the atmosphere, largely from carbon dioxide. The science is settled on this. The large concern is how much it will impact the world's agricultural system, water reserves, ecosystems, and longevity. The degree of impact is still largely dependent on how much nations and reduce their greenhouse gas emissions. To avoid cataclysmic potentials of climate change, we must stop emitting carbon dioxide. The problem is how rapidly. Repealing the CPP would delay this necessary shift to renewable energies to the future, which will not only jeopardize the future public health of the nation, but also the economy of the future when the US is finally, and rapidly, forced to adjust its power sources to renewables.

Second, the reasoning behind this repeal is based on faulty economic logic. The EPA claims that, under the new calculations the current administration has used, the repeal of the CPP will reduce costs of compliance by $33 Billion by 2030. I would like to address several issues with this. First, this cost is minimal compared to the overall scale of the economic growth by the year 2030. Assuming GDP stays at its current level of 18.5 trillion for GDP until 2030, this cost is around one one- hundredth of one percent of the economy. This is not an amount that unduly impedes the economic engine of the US, and thus not a good case to call for a repeal. Second, the cost of climate change is something that will affect all economies well beyond the year 2030, thus such a cost-benefit analysis ignores the geologic time scale the climate change will be impacting. Finally, I believe the cost of the human welfare into dollars and cents is not an effective way to assess the impact climate change will have. While a cost-benefit analysis is always something to consider, I do not believe that the subjective analysis preformed outweighs the physical trauma that repealing the CPP will impose in the future.

Lastly, I would like to comment on the legal grounds of the EPA's repeal of the CPP. The administrator claims that the Clean Power Plan would be an overreach of the EPA's regulative authority by "forcing" power utilities to invest in different sources of electricity to reach compliance of the CPP, and thus a repeal of the regulation is necessary. This seems like an arbitrary view of the agency's authority. With the logic proposed by the administrator, the EPA's allowance of credit exchanges for wetland mitigation banks or sulfur dioxide emissions could also be considered "outside-the-fence regulation". These programs are causing utilities to engage in mitigative strategies outside of their own facilities or properties to come into compliance with the EPA's regulations. If these programs are not considered to be "outside-the-fence", then neither should the CPP.

I hope that my comments are headed along with the thousands of concerned Americans who are concerned about the facts and logic the proposed repeal relies on, and would also appreciate a tolerable climate by the year 2100.

WIND TURBINES KILL OVER 100,000 BATS EACH YEAR.
VALUE OF BATS TO FARMERS, a single colony of 150 big brown bats (Eptesicus fuscus) in Indiana has been estimated to eat nearly 1.3 million pest insects each year, possibly contributing to the disruption of population cycles of agricultural pests . Other estimates suggest that a single little brown bat can consume 4 to 8 g of insects each night during the active season. clearly show how bats have enormous potential to influence the economics of agriculture and forestry.
VALUE OF BATS agriculture industry. is estimated nearly $23 billion per year, but may range from $3.7 billion to $53 billion a year. Brazilian free-tailed bats (Tadarida brasiliensis) form enormous summer breeding colonies, mostly in caves and under bridges, in south-central Texas and northern Mexico. Their prey includes several species of adult insects whose larvae are known to be important agricultural pests, including the corn earworm or cotton bollworm (Helicoverpa zea).
VALUE OF BATS; as beneficial pollinators Fruit-eating bats are sometimes called the farmers of the tropics because they are incredibly efficient at dispersing seeds. While some bats provide pest control, nectar-feeding pats act as beneficial pollinators. Giant cacti and agave are just two types of plants that depend on bats for pollination, and in the tropics, over 500 different types of tropical plants are pollinated by bats every year.
VALUE OF BATS TO FOREST: Theyre especially essential to regenerating clear-cut forests, which requires seeds to be dropped over large, open spaces .
VALUE OF BATS FOR REDUCED PESTICDES , pest suppression services provided by bats ranges from about $12 to $173/acre (with a most likely scenario of $74/acre) in a cotton-dominated agricultural landscape in south-central Texas. Means less Pesticides and chemicals on the crops that are not needed to suppress the insects consumed by bats which also reduces impacts of PESTICIDES on ecosystems, which can be substantial. Plus, reducing the potential for evolved resistance of insects to PESTICIDS ,,,and genetically modified crops,,,,,. , Without bats, crop yields are affected. Pesticide applications go up. bats can exert top down suppression of forest insects. The researchers noted that bats suppress pest-associated fungal growth and mycotoxin in corn as well as increased crop yield by 1.4 percent, which adds up to a difference of more than $3 an acre. study found that bats save farmers more than $1 billion worldwide and thats only for corn crops.
BATS VALUE as pest control for cotton production in an eight-county region in south-central Texas. Calculations show an annual value of $741 000 per year, with a range of $121 000$1 725 000, compared to a $4.6$6.4 million per year annual cotton harvest. Bats feed on some of the most damaging crop pests including the moths of cutworms and armyworms which helps to protect food crops naturally. Farmers appreciate the pest control provided by bats and many look forward to having bats return to their farms each year.

text:
I write to express my opposition to your March 15, 2018, proposal to weaken the critical protections provided by the 2015 coal ash rule.

This proposal will leave communities and our environment vulnerable to toxic coal ash contamination and catastrophic spills.

What part of these proposals does not spell DISASTER?

GUT GROUNDWATER PROTECTION STANDARDS

GUT GROUNDWATER MONITORING REQUIREMENTS

GUT CLEANUP REQUIREMENTS

GUT LOCATION RESTRICTIONS

GUT CLOSURE REQUIREMENTS FOR LEAKING UNLINED DUMPS

Why are we in this mess?

THE EPAS CURRENT HRULEMAKING PROCESS IS FLAWED AND LIMITS PUBLIC INPUT: The EPA has failed to consider widespread evidence of overwhelming groundwater contamination before proposing to weaken the coal ash rule. Industry data shows arsenic in groundwater near ash dumps exceeds federal drinking water standards at most plants. Dangerous levels of lead, thallium, selenium or radium are also very common. Moreover, 45 days is far too short a time for the public to provide meaningful comment. By failing to hold any field hearings in impacted communities, the EPA is silencing the voices of those directly harmed.

I urge you to protect Americans from coal ash and preserve all of the minimum protections provided by the 2015 coal ash rule.

You can do this now.

Regards,
Suzanne Guerra

docAbstract: The EPA is publishing a proposed rule addressing specific technical issues on which the Agency agreed to a remand as a result of litigation of the final Coal Combustion Residuals (CCR) Disposal Rule, published April 17, 2015. Issues covered by this proposal will include, but are not limited to, the height limitation of the vegetative slopes of dikes; the type and magnitude of non-groundwater releases that would require a facility to comply with some or all of the corrective action procedures set forth in the final CCR rule; and adding boron to the list of contaminants in Appendix IV of the final CCR rule that trigger the corrective action requirements under the final rule.

text:
I strongly oppose this cruel and dangerous proposal, which endangers animals, consumers, and American workers. Slaughter plants must not have free reign to kill at recklessly high speeds with poor oversight. An investigation by Compassion Over Killing of a pilot high-speed slaughter program exposed pigs dragged, kicked and excessively shocked by workers who could barely keep up -- risking human injury and compromising the safety of the food supply. Please abandon this proposal and instead focus on stopping the horrific cruelty that already exists in this industry.

Please remember that any stress the animal incurs, will eventually be in the body of the people who eat the animals.

Thank you for reading this.

docAbstract: The Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) is proposing to amend the Federal meat inspection regulations to establish a new inspection system for swine slaughter establishments. Swine slaughter establishments that do not choose to operate under the new swine inspection system may continue to operate under their current inspection system. The Agency is also proposing several changes that would affect all establishments that slaughter swine, regardless of the inspection system under which they operate.

text:
You have a job to protect the health of the American people. People who breathe the air and drink the water. Companies owe their loyalty to profits, but your job is to protect health. We need you to do your job to keep us healthy, not to protect companies' bottom line. Please do your job. I am opposed to any attempt to repeal or weaken clean water protections around toxic coal ash.

Clean water is the lifeblood of our communities, but too many of us have to worry about pollution leaking from coal ash ponds, threatening our drinking water and the health of our families.

We cannot rely on the utilities and coal ash pond operators to set their own standards or decide if they want to clean up their pollution, as your current proposal allows. These and a host of other provisions in the proposal, like eliminating requirements for leaking ponds to install liners, seem to prioritize industry profits over our public health, and should be abandoned.

text:
Dear NMFS,

As an angler, I am opposed to plans to revitalize the U.S. Atlantic pelagic longline fishery. This goal comes at the expense of bluefin tuna, marlin, and the recreational fishing industry, which generates hundreds of thousands of jobs and contributes billions to the economy. Many of the options put forth in the Scoping Document do not further fish conservation or stock recovery.

I ask the National Marine Fisheries Service to, instead of bolstering the fishery responsible for closures and gear restrictions, take action to bolster bluefin tuna and marlin fish stocks. At a minimum, the "no action" option should be taken to maintain current closures and restricted areas. Please consider management options that achieve greater conservation benefits for Atlantic bluefin tuna and marlin.

Thank you,

Jeffrey Liederman
label: veryneg
docAbstract: NMFS announces its intent to prepare a draft EIS to assess the potential effects of alternative measures under the 2006 Consolidated Atlantic Highly Migratory Species Fishery Management Plan (2006 Consolidated HMS FMP) for management of the pelagic longline fishery.  This notice announces a public process for determining the scope of issues to be addressed and for identifying the significant issues relating to the management of Atlantic HMS, with a focus on area-based management measures and weak hook management measures that were implemented to reduce dead discards of bluefin tuna in the pelagic longline fishery.  NMFS would use the scoping process and the draft EIS to develop a regulatory amendment applicable to the pelagic longline fishery.  The scoping process and draft EIS are intended to determine if the suite of existing measures are the best means of achieving the current management objectives and providing flexibility to adapt to fishing variability in the future, consistent with the 2006 Consolidated HMS FMP, the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (Magnuson-Stevens Act), the Atlantic Tunas Convention Act (ATCA), and other relevant Federal laws.  NMFS is also announcing the availability of a scoping document describing potential measures for inclusion in a future regulatory amendment.  NMFS will hold scoping meetings to gather public comment on potential management options for area based and weak hook requirements.  The time and location details of the scoping meetings are available in the SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION section of this notice.  NMFS is requesting comments on this NOI and the management of Atlantic bluefin tuna, which includes management options that are described in the scoping document, and relevant options that would meet the purpose and need for this action.

text:
There is a reason restrictions were put in place to help protect the land, water, and air from pollutants. Without regulations and guidance, the ones creating the pollution didn't make an effort to stop. We need to continue to protect the environment. Lives, human and otherwise, depend on clean water, air, and land, to be healthy.
I am opposed to any attempt to repeal or weaken clean water protections around toxic coal ash.

Clean water is the lifeblood of our communities, but too many of us have to worry about pollution leaking from coal ash ponds, threatening our drinking water and the health of our families.

We cannot rely on the utilities and coal ash pond operators to set their own standards or decide if they want to clean up their pollution, as your current proposal allows. These and a host of other provisions in the proposal, like eliminating requirements for leaking ponds to install liners, seem to prioritize industry profits over our public health, and should be abandoned.

text:
I am opposed to any attempt to repeal or weaken clean water protections around toxic coal ash.

Clean water is the lifeblood of our communities, but too many of us have to worry about pollution leaking from coal ash ponds, threatening our drinking water and the health of our families.

We cannot rely on the utilities and coal ash pond operators to set their own standards or decide if they want to clean up their pollution, as your current proposal allows. These and a host of other provisions in the proposal, like eliminating requirements for leaking ponds to install liners, seem to prioritize industry profits over our public health, and should be abandoned.

It has always been my understanding that the EPAs mission is to protect US citizens from deadly pollution caused by industrial waste. Giving the big polluters permission to write their own rules now will result in future damage or death to citizens. Surely, if that is not the underlying intent of this administration, you will not give utilities that power because they will always choose profits over unnamed people.

text:
Dear NMFS,
As an angler, I am opposed to plans to revitalize the U.S. Atlantic pelagic longline fishery. This goal comes at the expense of bluefin tuna, marlin, and the recreational fishing industry, which generates hundreds of thousands of jobs and contributes billions to the economy. Many of the options put forth in the Scoping Document do not further fish conservation or stock recovery.
I ask the National Marine Fisheries Service to, instead of bolstering the fishery responsible for closures and gear restrictions, take action to bolster bluefin tuna and marlin fish stocks. At a minimum, the "no action" option should be taken to maintain current closures and restricted areas. Please consider management options that achieve greater conservation benefits for Atlantic bluefin tuna and marlin.
Thank you,

deVane Batchelor
label: veryneg
docAbstract: NMFS announces its intent to prepare a draft EIS to assess the potential effects of alternative measures under the 2006 Consolidated Atlantic Highly Migratory Species Fishery Management Plan (2006 Consolidated HMS FMP) for management of the pelagic longline fishery.  This notice announces a public process for determining the scope of issues to be addressed and for identifying the significant issues relating to the management of Atlantic HMS, with a focus on area-based management measures and weak hook management measures that were implemented to reduce dead discards of bluefin tuna in the pelagic longline fishery.  NMFS would use the scoping process and the draft EIS to develop a regulatory amendment applicable to the pelagic longline fishery.  The scoping process and draft EIS are intended to determine if the suite of existing measures are the best means of achieving the current management objectives and providing flexibility to adapt to fishing variability in the future, consistent with the 2006 Consolidated HMS FMP, the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (Magnuson-Stevens Act), the Atlantic Tunas Convention Act (ATCA), and other relevant Federal laws.  NMFS is also announcing the availability of a scoping document describing potential measures for inclusion in a future regulatory amendment.  NMFS will hold scoping meetings to gather public comment on potential management options for area based and weak hook requirements.  The time and location details of the scoping meetings are available in the SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION section of this notice.  NMFS is requesting comments on this NOI and the management of Atlantic bluefin tuna, which includes management options that are described in the scoping document, and relevant options that would meet the purpose and need for this action.

text:
I write to express my opposition to your March 15, 2018, proposal to weaken the critical protections provided by the 2015 coal ash rule. Below I outline how your proposal will leave communities and our environment vulnerable to toxic coal ash contamination and catastrophic spills.

GUTTING OF GROUNDWATER PROTECTION STANDARDS: I oppose your proposal to weaken the groundwater protection standards. Thousands of massive, aging coal ash pits are leaking heavy metals and toxic pollutants into groundwater. Coal ash dumping has led to water contamination and disastrous coal ash spills. Your proposal to allow states and polluters to use "alternative" groundwater protection standards for determining when cleanup is required will only enable states and polluters to hide the truth about contamination.

GUTTING OF GROUNDWATER MONITORING REQUIREMENTS: The public deserves to know if coal ash dumps in their communities are contaminating groundwater. The groundwater monitoring requirements are vitally important to the more than 15 million households in the U.S. that rely on private wells for drinking water. It's unconscionable to allow polluters to decide when groundwater monitoring should stop.

GUTTING OF CLEANUP REQUIREMENTS: Empowering polluters to avoid cleanup will result in ongoing water contamination. Allowing states or the owners of leaking dumps to determine whether cleanup or closure is necessary is dangerous. Coal ash is toxic, and weakening current standards to match those of town dumps endangers all communities that are near coal ash ponds and landfills. And just because a coal ash dump is no longer receiving waste doesn't mean that it no longer poses a threat to health and the environment. I oppose your proposal to treat coal ash like household garbage and to reduce the 30-year post-closure monitoring period for dumps that are no longer receiving waste.

GUTTING OF LOCATION RESTRICTIONS: Prohibitions on dumping coal ash in groundwater, wetlands, floodplains, fault zones, seismic zones and unstable areas are commonsense requirements that prevent water contamination. I oppose your proposal to give states and polluters the discretion to ignore crucial and life-saving location prohibitions (and to do so without public notification or oversight), and reject any extension of the October 2018 deadline to comply with these requirements.

GUTTING CLOSURE REQUIREMENTS FOR LEAKING UNLINED DUMPS: I strongly oppose your proposal to give states and polluters the discretion not to close or retrofit dangerous leaking unlined pits. If these leaking dumps are allowed to operate, they will keep polluting our drinking water and waterways and continue to threaten catastrophic spills.

THE EPAS CURRENT RULEMAKING PROCESS IS FLAWED AND LIMITS PUBLIC INPUT: The EPA has failed to consider widespread evidence of overwhelming groundwater contamination before proposing to weaken the coal ash rule. Industry data shows arsenic in groundwater near ash dumps exceeds federal drinking water standards at most plants. Dangerous levels of lead, thallium, selenium or radium are also very common. Moreover, 45 days is far too short a time for the public to provide meaningful comment. By failing to hold any field hearings in impacted communities, the EPA is silencing the voices of those directly harmed.

I urge you to protect us from coal ash and preserve all of the minimum protections provided by the 2015 coal ash rule.

Lastly, it is sad for this country and it's only significant environmental protection agency with any effect still allow coal to be used a power source in this age of scientific enlightenment of viable energy alternatives. The very existence of these draconian protrusions in the energy manufacturing pantheon not only allows these plants to perpetuate but gives the power wealthy families of these utterly backwards energy choices the latitude to make laws that overtly and covertly kill any possibility of proven energy alternatives to take root. The cleaner coal argument is false in its foundation- a continuation of coal magnates from decades ago entrenched in the American political scheme. Magnates that hold influence over the very best of protection agencys established and for reasons they don't even think about on any given day.

Please consider our plea.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Justin Peek

Regards,
Justin Peek

text:
I am opposed to any attempt to repeal or weaken laws that do or would provide clean air, ground, and water protection from toxic coal ash.

I know a bit about this: My mother grew up in W Va. years ago. Many of her relatives remained there after she moved away with her husband. Others in the family have also moved but were nearby and could continue to visit when possible. They kept the rest of us informed on conditions.

Few people understand the ruinous and toxic nature of coal mining, which is even worse above ground (strip and mountaintop mining) than it was below ground.

Mountains without trees enable storm flooding, which kills people as well as destroying their homes AND their health; the floods deposit toxins in streams that poison vegetable gardens and water supplies
.
Clean water is the lifeblood of our communities, but in coal country, many citizens still have to worry about pollution leaking from coal ash ponds, threatening their drinking water and the health of their families.

CLEARLY, the public CANNOT rely on the utilities and coal ash pond operators to set healthy standards or decide if they want to clean up their pollution, AS YOUR CURRENT PROPOSAL ALLOWS, along with other provisions, such as eliminating requirements to install liners in polluted and leaking ponds, prioritizing industry profits over our public health, and so on (and on).

Your first priority should have been the health of the American people whom you were supposed to protect. YOU HAVE FAILED!

text:
I want to express in the strongest possible terms my opposition to the proposal to weaken rules governing disposal of coal ash. Coal ash is a toxic material known to contain heavy metals and other materials that are hazardous to human health and to our natural world. As a physician, I know we need to strengthen not weaken guidelines for coal ash disposal. There are approaches such as binding coal ash in ceramic bricks that are known to minimize risk of toxic water and air pollution. Why wouldn't we insist that safer disposal methods be required--unfortunately, probably because vested interests want to reduce cost. This is not acceptable. The Environmental Protection Agency is a "Protection" agency with a primary goal of protecting U.S. citizens and our nation from environmental harm. Peoples' lives depend on this! Don't let the American people down and don't weaken rules governing the disposal of coal ash!
Sincerely

The Agency is also proposing several changes that would affect all establishments that slaughter swine, regardless of the inspection system under which they operate.

text:
Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,

I strongly oppose this cruel and dangerous proposal, which endangers animals, customers and American workers. Slaughter plants must not have free reign to kill at recklessly high speeds with poor oversight. An investigation by Compassion Over Killing of a pilot high-speed slaughter program exposed pigs dragged, kicked and excessively shocked by workers who could barely keep up - risking human injury and compromising the safety of the food supply. Please abandon this proposal and instead focus on stopping the horrific cruelty that already exists in this industry.

Sincerely,

Jrg Gaiser
Baiersbronn
Germany

text:
Dear NMFS,
As an angler, I am opposed to plans to revitalize the U.S. Atlantic pelagic longline fishery. This goal comes at the expense of bluefin tuna, marlin, and the recreational fishing industry, which generates hundreds of thousands of jobs and contributes billions to the economy. Many of the options put forth in the Scoping Document do not further fish conservation or stock recovery.
I ask the National Marine Fisheries Service to, instead of bolstering the fishery responsible for closures and gear restrictions, take action to bolster bluefin tuna and marlin fish stocks. At a minimum, the "no action" option should be taken to maintain current closures and restricted areas. Please consider management options that achieve greater conservation benefits for Atlantic bluefin tuna and marlin.
Thank you,

Sam Moore
Houston, TX
label: veryneg
docAbstract: NMFS announces its intent to prepare a draft EIS to assess the potential effects of alternative measures under the 2006 Consolidated Atlantic Highly Migratory Species Fishery Management Plan (2006 Consolidated HMS FMP) for management of the pelagic longline fishery.  This notice announces a public process for determining the scope of issues to be addressed and for identifying the significant issues relating to the management of Atlantic HMS, with a focus on area-based management measures and weak hook management measures that were implemented to reduce dead discards of bluefin tuna in the pelagic longline fishery.  NMFS would use the scoping process and the draft EIS to develop a regulatory amendment applicable to the pelagic longline fishery.  The scoping process and draft EIS are intended to determine if the suite of existing measures are the best means of achieving the current management objectives and providing flexibility to adapt to fishing variability in the future, consistent with the 2006 Consolidated HMS FMP, the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (Magnuson-Stevens Act), the Atlantic Tunas Convention Act (ATCA), and other relevant Federal laws.  NMFS is also announcing the availability of a scoping document describing potential measures for inclusion in a future regulatory amendment.  NMFS will hold scoping meetings to gather public comment on potential management options for area based and weak hook requirements.  The time and location details of the scoping meetings are available in the SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION section of this notice.  NMFS is requesting comments on this NOI and the management of Atlantic bluefin tuna, which includes management options that are described in the scoping document, and relevant options that would meet the purpose and need for this action.

docAbstract: The EPA is publishing a proposed rule addressing specific technical issues on which the Agency agreed to a remand as a result of litigation of the final Coal Combustion Residuals (CCR) Disposal Rule, published April 17, 2015. Issues covered by this proposal will include, but are not limited to, the height limitation of the vegetative slopes of dikes; the type and magnitude of non-groundwater releases that would require a facility to comply with some or all of the corrective action procedures set forth in the final CCR rule; and adding boron to the list of contaminants in Appendix IV of the final CCR rule that trigger the corrective action requirements under the final rule.

text:
As a concerned citizen of Alabama, I respectfully submit the following comments to express my opposition to the proposed rule.

Due to (1) the major threat coal ash poses to public health, (2) the history of unlined and leaking storage ponds in Alabama, and (3) the positive provisions of the 2015 coal ash rule, I oppose the loopholes and flexibilities within this proposed rule. The proposal seeks to roll back the 2015 rule in favor of a scheme that allows power plants to set their own standards and escape accountability. These provisions will harm communities in Alabama and across the country.

Alabama is fraught with cautionary tales about the dangers of coal ash. For decades, the states nine active and inactive power plants have burned coal. As a result, more than 100 million cubic yards of coal ash exists in Alabama. There are around two dozen coal ash pits; nearly every one is an unlined pond leaking directly into an important river or stream. Coal ash contains carcinogens, toxins, and heavy metals -- all of which have repeatedly contaminated groundwater, private wells, and rivers used for drinking water. The 2018 groundwater monitoring reports showed dangerous contamination surrounding all six coal ash facilities in the state. Additionally, Uniontown, Alabama now stores ash from the 2008 Kingston spill; the town claims serious degradation of health and quality of life thanks to improper storage.

DISCRETIONARY REMEDIATION AND MONITORING: The proposed rule would allow facilities to avoid remediation when contaminated waters are not hydrologically connected to drinking waters, or are polluted by other sources. This scheme allows pollution to go unpunished and fails to protect wildlife and riverine health. Facilities may also evade regular monitoring under certain findings. Knowing how severe contamination is in Alabama, these provisions impose too much unnecessary risk for communities near storage ponds.

WEAKER WATER QUALITY STANDARDS: The current rule requires closure and cleanup when pollutants exceed EPAs water quality standards. The proposal would allow states to work with polluters to set less protective standards. This rollback puts Alabamians at risk by subjecting them to waters in exceedance of what is scientifically and legally safe.

CLOSURE REQUIREMENTS: The proposed rule would allow unlined, leaking ponds to remain open. States and polluters would get to determine whether closure is necessary. Political pressure and economic incentives may jeopardize public safety, causing facilities to stay open despite dangerous pollution.

ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND PUBLIC PARTICIPATION: Certain underrepresented communities in Alabama will be disproportionately affected because of these rollbacks. Due to the complexity of coal ash storage and EPAs accelerated timeline, those communities will largely go unheard.

I oppose the proposed rule, as it will hurt water quality, human health, and riverine ecology. I urge the EPA to protect the environment and public health by withdrawing this proposal.

Sincerely,
Eartha McGoldrick

text:
March 28, 2017 EXECUTIVE ORDER PROMOTING ENERGY INDEPENDENCE AND ECONOMIC GROWTH,
Sec. 2. Immediate Review of All Agency Actions that Potentially Burden the Safe, Efficient Development of Domestic Energy Resources. (b) For purposes of this order, "burden" means to unnecessarily obstruct, delay, curtail, or otherwise impose significant costs on the siting, permitting, production, utilization, transmission, or delivery of energy resources.
Sec. 3. Rescission of Certain Energy and Climate-Related Presidential and Regulatory Actions.
(a) The following Presidential actions are hereby revoked: (i) Executive Order 13653 of November 1, 2013 (Preparing the United States for the Impacts of Climate Change); (ii) The Presidential Memorandum of June 25, 2013 (Power Sector Carbon Pollution Standards); (iii) The Presidential Memorandum of November 3, 2015 (Mitigating Impacts on Natural Resources from Development and Encouraging Related Private Investment); and (iv) The Presidential Memorandum of September 21, 2016 (Climate Change and National Security). (b) The following reports shall be rescinded: (i) The Report of the Executive Office of the President of June 2013 (The President's Climate Action Plan); and (ii) The Report of the Executive Office of the President of March 2014 (Climate Action Plan Strategy to Reduce Methane Emissions). c) The Council on Environmental Quality shall rescind its final guidance entitled "Final Guidance for Federal Departments and Agencies on Consideration of Greenhouse Gas Emissions and the Effects of Climate Change in National Environmental Policy Act Reviews," which is referred to in "Notice of Availability," 81 Fed. Reg. 51866 (August 5, 2016) Sec. 5. Review of Estimates of the Social Cost of Carbon, Nitrous Oxide, and Methane for Regulatory Impact Analysis.
(a) In order to ensure sound regulatory decision making, it is essential that agencies use estimates of costs and benefits in their regulatory analyses that are based on the best available science and economics.
(b) The Interagency Working Group on Social Cost of Greenhouse Gases (IWG), which was convened by the Council of Economic Advisers and the OMB Director, shall be disbanded, and the following documents issued by the IWG shall be withdrawn as no longer representative of governmental policy: (i) Technical Support Document: Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory Impact Analysis Under Executive Order 12866 (February 2010); (ii) Technical Update of the Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory Impact Analysis (May 2013); (iii) Technical Update of the Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory Impact Analysis (November 2013); (iv) Technical Update of the Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory Impact Analysis (July 2015); (v) Addendum to the Technical Support Document for Social Cost of Carbon: Application of the Methodology to Estimate the Social Cost of Methane and the Social Cost of Nitrous Oxide (August 2016); and (vi) Technical Update of the Social Cost of Carbon for Regulatory Impact Analysis (August 2016).
(c) Effective immediately, when monetizing the value of changes in greenhouse gas emissions resulting from regulations, including with respect to the consideration of domestic versus international impacts and the consideration of appropriate discount rates, agencies shall ensure, to the extent permitted by law, that any such estimates are consistent with the guidance contained in OMB Circular A-4 of September 17, 2003 (Regulatory Analysis), which was issued after peer review and public comment and has been widely accepted for more than a decade as embodying the best practices for conducting regulatory cost-benefit analysis.

text:
As a recreational angler and conservationist, I support Amendment 43 to the Fishery Management Plan for the Snapper-Grouper Fishery of the South Atlantic Region that would allow a limited opening of the red snapper fishery in South Atlantic federal waters.

I support opening a South Atlantic red snapper season in 2018, through Amendment 43, that balances season length with sustainability. The South Atlantic red snapper stock has increased in abundance over the last several years at an even faster rate than predicted by the rebuilding plan. Abundance surveys and angler reports point to a quickly rebuilding fishery. Opening a conservative season as proposed will not only provide access and opportunity for anglers, but will also provide much needed data for a more accurate assessment of the red snapper stock.

In conclusion, I support Snapper Grouper Amendment 43 and urge swift final approval by the Secretary of Commerce.

Thank you for your consideration.
label: pos
docAbstract: NMFS proposes regulations to implement Amendment 43.  In November 2017, NMFS implemented an emergency rule that set the 2017 commercial and recreational annual catch limit (ACL) for red snapper in the South Atlantic at 42,510 fish.  Prior to the recent emergency action, the ACL was zero and harvest was not allowed since 2014.  The actions in Amendment 43 will remove the process and equation used to determine the red snapper ACL as specified in Amendment 28 to the Snapper-Grouper FMP.  In addition, this action will specify a total ACL equal to 42,510 fish, a commercial ACL equal to 124,815 pounds (whole weight), and a recreational ACL equal to 29,656 fish to allow harvest of red snapper beginning in 2018.   The action is expected  to reduce, to the extent practicable, existing adverse socio-economic impacts to fishermen and fishing communities that utilize the red snapper portion of the snapper-grouper fishery, without overfishing, and while continuing to rebuild the stock as per the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act.

text:
The Clean Power Plan should be repealed by the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) because a number of scientists and environmental leaders around the world are communicating that in fact climate science is not settled as some leaders have promoted for political reasons. In addition, a leading environment activist has reported that anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions are beneficial to life on earth rather than endangering life on earth.

For example, Patrick Moore, the co-founder of Greenpeace, released a paper in June 2016 entitled, "The Positive Impact of Human CO2 Emissions on the Survival of Life on Earth." A key point by Moore is that the earth's atmospheric CO2 levels were trending below 180 parts per million (ppm) such that the earth's atmosphere would lack sufficient CO2 to sustain plant life. An electronic file of Moore's report is included with these comments.

Moore provided three critical findings: (1) "Human emissions of CO2 have restored a balance to the global carbon cycle, thereby ensuring the long-term continuation of life on Earth.", (2) "The extremely positive aspect of human CO2 emissions must be weighed against the unproven hypothesis that human CO2 emissions will cause a catastrophic warming of the climate in coming years.", and (3) "The one-sided political treatment of CO2 as a pollutant that should be radically reduced must be corrected in light of the indisputable scientific evidence that it is essential to life on Earth."

As a life-long environmental activist and leader, Moore's findings are profound in that they are counter to the prevailing political wisdom concerning the effects of anthropogenic CO2 emissions as presenting great negative consequences and endangering life on Earth. The ramifications identified by Moore are that our world would begin to face food shortages and would become increasingly challenged to feed the world's growing population. This is especially noteworthy as countries around the world strive to transition large population groups from extreme poverty to middle class quality of life and education. Moore identifies anthropogenic CO2 as a providing a positive impact in forestalling/preventing a food crisis on earth and allowing people to be lifted out of poverty.

In addition, reports issued by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) found, "The current rate of global mean sea level change, starting in the late 19th - early 20th century, is, with medium confidence, unusually high in the context of centennial-scale variations of the last two millennia." The IPCC's definition of "medium confidence" rates findings at a 50% chance of being correct, which also means that this finding is rated at a 50% chance of being wrong. Surely a 50-50 chance of being right or wrong is not settled science.

Furthermore, the IPCC report provides "very high confidence" findings that actual historical precedent for glacial cycles prior to anthropogenic CO2 emissions have resulted in at least 5 meter sea level rise higher than at present and that rising sea level is to be expected following the Little Ice Age. Therefore, it would be intellectually incorrect to assign recent rise in sea level rise solely to anthropogenic CO2 emissions since the Little Ice Age ended circa 1750.

These facts from the IPCC report are important because they identify non-anthropogenic CO2 emission factors predominately responsible for rising sea level that are not being addressed in solution discussions given the incorrect political focus on anthropogenic CO2 emissions as the root cause. Clarifying the correct root cause(s) is extremely important to ensure that efforts to prevent the estimated damage due to rising sea levels are properly focused on solutions that actually address the true root cause(s). Failure to do so will allow the estimated damage to occur.

So, it is vitally important that U.S. and international policies concerning responses to rising sea level properly understand the controlling factors and the beneficial contributions of higher than 180ppm atmospheric CO2 levels to global food production so as to effectively refocus solution efforts more appropriately. Key steps toward appropriately addressing rising sea levels is to repeal the Clean Power Plan, repeal the EPA's endangerment finding on CO2, and to focus efforts and resources on solutions to address rising sea level damage.

text:
The FDA does not need to be in the business of regulating or restricting the sale or marketing of, or taxing the sale of, premium cigars.

I oppose the imposition of a costly pre-market review process for premium cigars. Pre-market review would be cost prohibitive for many manufacturers, effectively eliminating their ability to release special editions and seasonal blends. Such products are a distinctive aspect of the industry and a large part of what consumers like myself are looking for and enjoy.

I oppose a ban on sampling. Product sampling is an integral part of the unique experience at a premium cigar shop. A sampling ban would prohibit consumers like myself from being able to try new products in my shop and at cigar charity events, which drive consumer purchasing. Given the typical price point and celebratory nature of premium cigars, customers are less likely to purchase an unfamiliar product.

I oppose an arbitrary price point for a cigar to be deemed "premium. Premium cigars, those that are, but not limited to, defined as being hand rolled, quality, humidity controlled, cigars, are not what underage children go for. They are not addictive like cigarettes, they are not consumed with anywhere near the regularity of cigarettes, and to confuse their use with cigarette use is problematic.

For thes reasons, it is critical that the FDA consider the difference between premium cigars and other tobacco products when drafting the final regulations. Premium cigars are an adult product, without the habitual use patterns of mass-market tobacco products. Existing state law prohibits the sale of products to minors.

I urge you to exempt premium cigars from the final FDA regulations. Imposing one-size-fits-all regulations on a diverse suite of tobacco products is a step in the wrong direction for the FDA. Thank you for the opportunity to submit comment on the proposed deeming regulations.

Thank you.

It was a way to relax, bond with other members of the military from other countries and for a small window of time, forget we were in the middle of a war and that people were trying to kill us everyday. I also worked as an infectious disease subject matter expert for the military as well as an expert in the field protection, detection and decontamination of chemical and biological weapons materials and toxic industrial chemicals.
The regulation of cigarettes is something I agree with but not cigars. The smoker does not inhale cigar smoke and the majority of the toxins in cigarettes comes from the chemicals used to treat the paper and tobacco. Premium cigars are not treated with any chemicals, they are totally a natural product.
Thank you for listening,
LtCol Mitchell E Fadem, PhD

text:
Hazardous and Solid Waste Management System: Disposal of Coal Combustion Residuals From Electric Utilities; Amendments to the National Minimum Criteria (Phase One); Proposed Rule
Docket ID No.EPA-HQ-OLEM-2017-0286
Comment submitted by: Dale Timmons, R.G., NAES Corporation

This comment is pursuant to:
257.73 and 257.74

The preamble references:
1.FEMA 534, FEMA (2005b),

2.U.S. Army Corps of Engineers' ''ETL 1110-2- 583:

FEMA 534 addresses earthen dams that contain water.
The Corps document states: "Levees, floodwalls, embankment dams, and their appurtenant structures serve a common purpose in that they are designed to contain water and prevent flooding...."

The proposed CCR revision and the references cited address structural integrity of containment structures that are used for containing water or CCRs that impose a hydraulic head on these structures or that are subject to liquefaction.

The intent of the rule is to maintain containment integrity so that catastrophic spills or releases are avoided. References state that woody or other undesirable plants adversely affect the integrity of containment structures and increase the risks of failures and spills.

Neither the proposed rule, or the references cited address structures that enclose non-flowable materials nor do they consider the minimal risk that these structures represent.

Power generators are exploring or implementing methods for CCR compliance. One of these methods is solidification and stabilization of CCRs using the self-cementing capacity of fly ash, or additives such as Portland cement or lime.

Some practices include the removal of CCRs from an impoundment followed by solidification and placement back into the impoundment, or solidification in place. Regardless of the method used, the result is a solid product that is not susceptible to liquification and does not impose hydraulic pressure on containment structures. These facilities contain little to no accumulated water. Precipitation that falls on these structures is managed as runoff and promptly removed. Thus, no appreciable quantity of water is ever contained within impoundments that contain solidified CCRs.

It known that trees and deep root structures contribute to slope stability and inhibit erosion (Ref: I,ii,iii). These references document reduced slope stability caused by removal of trees from activities that involve tree removal. They clearly show that trees and their roots enhance slope stability and that their removal results in erosion, slope instability and landslides.

A solidified CCR disposal facility is referenced where trees are intentionally used to enhance slope stability. Thjis is the Matra Plant near Budapest, Hungary. It contains 25 million cu. yds of solidified CCRs in a tiered impoundment that covers 314 acres at its base and 200 acres on top and is 150 ft. high. It has been in operation for 20 years and the slopes are planted with trees. The facility reached its permitted height and was closed in 2015. Then, the top was developed to support a solar collection facility that generates 18.5 MW. The solar collection facility alone demonstrates the stability of the entire structure.
This facility has not experienced any slope failures or slope stability issues during its operation.

Photo of Matra Facility included in attached file

The purpose of this comment is to encourage EPA to recognize that:

1.Woody plants and trees enhance the stability and erosional resistance of sloped structures that are not subject to hydraulic pressure.

2.CCRs that have been mixed with solidification agents are placed into impoundments in lifts that are only a few inches deep before solidifying. This is not deep enough to impart hydraulic pressure of any consequence.

3.Rain that falls on impoundments containing solidified CCRs is managed as runoff and is promptly removed thus preventing accumulations of more than a few inches.

We respectfully request that the revised rule be modified to allow the presence of woody plants and trees on the slopes of structures that surround solidified CCRs.

The commenter, Dale Timmons is a Registered Geologist and Hydrogeologist in Oregon and Washington. Mr. Timmons has extensive experience in rock/soil mechanics, slope stability. In addition, he has extensive experience with ash/wastewater management, particularly in the field of solidification and stabilization of ash and wastewater originating from coal fired power plants.

References:
Ziemer, R.R., The role of Vegetation in the Stability of Forested Slopes, Pacific Southwest Forest and Range Experiment Station Forest Service, U.S. Department of Agriculture,

Slope Stability Reference Guide for National Forests in the United States, Volume I, U.S. Department of Agriculture, EM-7170-13, 1994

Reid, L.M., Implications of the USGS Analysis of Slope Stability at Sulphur Creek, USDA Forest Service Pacific Southwest Research Station Redwood Sciences Laboratory.

text:
Low carbohydrate diets have been proven safe and effective for decades. They have been used to treat a number of disorders, including obesity, diabetes and epilepsy. Low carbohydrate diets have been shown to be effective at losing weight and correcting dyslipidemia, such as high LDL cholesterol and elevated triglycerides.

The standard high-carbohydrate American diet has lead to the majority of Americans to be in a chronic state of hyperglycemia. This has lead to the development of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, even in children, and an epidemic of metabolic syndrome that has shown no sign of abating.

Another American epidemic that is associated with high-carbohydrate diets is Alzheimer's disease, which is the 6th leading cause of death in the United States and will cost the nation $277 billion in 2018. This could be significantly reduced by recommending low-carbohydrate diets for those with chronic hyperglycemia.

I have attached an annotated guide that I've put together which indicates how high levels of carbohydrates cause various forms of metabolic syndrome and mental dysfunction.

Thank you for taking the time to consider this consequential matter.
